outcomes.title: Algebraic properties
outcomes.description: State, justify, and apply basic properties of groups, rings, and fields

exercises.pretext:
1. Let a set S have binary operations + and \cdot defined. Explain the requirements for S to be a group (with operation +), ring, or field.

  2. One of the below Cayley tables does not define a group. Give an example illustrating how it satisfies or fails each of the requirements for a group.

    \hspace{1em} \begin{array}{c|cccccc} \circ & a&b&c&d&f&g\\\hline a & b & a & c & f & d & g \\ b & a & b & c & d & f & g \\ c & c & c & c & g & g & g \\ d & f & d & g & f & d & g \\ f & d & f & g & d & f & g \\ g & g & g & g & g & g & g \end{array} \hspace{1em} \begin{array}{c|cccccc} \cdot & 2&4&6&8&10&12\\\hline 2 & 12 & 10 & 8 & 6 & 4 & 2 \\ 4 & 8 & 12 & 10 & 2 & 6 & 4 \\ 6 & 10 & 8 & 12 & 4 & 2 & 6 \\ 8 & 4 & 6 & 2 & 10 & 12 & 8 \\ 10 & 6 & 2 & 4 & 12 & 8 & 10 \\ 12 & 2 & 4 & 6 & 8 & 10 & 12 \end{array} \hspace{1em}

  3. Use results from Section 3.1 to explain why \mathbb Z_{11} is a field, but \mathbb Z_{14} is only a ring.

N/A
exercises.html:
1. Let a set \(S\) have binary operations \(+\) and \(\cdot\) defined. Explain the requirements for \(S\) to be a group (with operation \(+\)), ring, or field.

  2. One of the below Cayley tables does not define a group. Give an example illustrating how it satisfies or fails each of the requirements for a group.

    \[ \hspace{1em} \begin{array}{c|cccccc} \circ & a&b&c&d&f&g\\\hline a & b & a & c & f & d & g \\ b & a & b & c & d & f & g \\ c & c & c & c & g & g & g \\ d & f & d & g & f & d & g \\ f & d & f & g & d & f & g \\ g & g & g & g & g & g & g \end{array} \hspace{1em} \begin{array}{c|cccccc} \cdot & 2&4&6&8&10&12\\\hline 2 & 12 & 10 & 8 & 6 & 4 & 2 \\ 4 & 8 & 12 & 10 & 2 & 6 & 4 \\ 6 & 10 & 8 & 12 & 4 & 2 & 6 \\ 8 & 4 & 6 & 2 & 10 & 12 & 8 \\ 10 & 6 & 2 & 4 & 12 & 8 & 10 \\ 12 & 2 & 4 & 6 & 8 & 10 & 12 \end{array} \hspace{1em} \]

  3. Use results from https://books.aimath.org/aata/section-mod-n-sym.html to explain why \(\mathbb Z_{11}\) is a field, but \(\mathbb Z_{14}\) is only a ring.

Answer:

N/A

exercises.pretext:
1. Let a set S have binary operations + and \cdot defined. Explain the requirements for S to be a group (with operation +), ring, or field.

  2. One of the below Cayley tables does not define a group. Give an example illustrating how it satisfies or fails each of the requirements for a group.

    \hspace{1em} \begin{array}{c|cccccc} \circ & 2&4&6&8&10&12\\\hline 2 & 8 & 12 & 2 & 2 & 8 & 12 \\ 4 & 12 & 4 & 4 & 12 & 4 & 12 \\ 6 & 2 & 4 & 6 & 8 & 10 & 12 \\ 8 & 2 & 12 & 8 & 8 & 2 & 12 \\ 10 & 8 & 4 & 10 & 2 & 6 & 12 \\ 12 & 12 & 12 & 12 & 12 & 12 & 12 \end{array} \hspace{1em} \begin{array}{c|cccccc} \cdot & a&b&c&d&f&g\\\hline a & g & d & b & c & a & f \\ b & c & f & a & g & b & d \\ c & d & g & f & a & c & b \\ d & b & a & g & f & d & c \\ f & a & b & c & d & f & g \\ g & f & c & d & b & g & a \end{array} \hspace{1em}

  3. Use results from Section 3.1 to explain why \mathbb Z_{17} is a field, but \mathbb Z_{18} is only a ring.

N/A
exercises.html:
1. Let a set \(S\) have binary operations \(+\) and \(\cdot\) defined. Explain the requirements for \(S\) to be a group (with operation \(+\)), ring, or field.

  2. One of the below Cayley tables does not define a group. Give an example illustrating how it satisfies or fails each of the requirements for a group.

  3. Use results from https://books.aimath.org/aata/section-mod-n-sym.html to explain why \(\mathbb Z_{17}\) is a field, but \(\mathbb Z_{18}\) is only a ring.

Answer:

N/A

exercises.pretext:
1. Let a set S have binary operations + and \cdot defined. Explain the requirements for S to be a group (with operation +), ring, or field.

  2. One of the below Cayley tables does not define a group. Give an example illustrating how it satisfies or fails each of the requirements for a group.

  3. Use results from Section 3.1 to explain why \mathbb Z_{11} is a field, but \mathbb Z_{16} is only a ring.

N/A

exercises.pretext:
1. Let a set S have binary operations + and \cdot defined. Explain the requirements for S to be a group (with operation +), ring, or field.
